Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <passcombo.com üè¥‚ò†üçã> it will be interesting experiment and sooner or later there will be distributed profile, working in analogical way google page rank based on links - people will confirm each other to gain trust, but for sure new challenges will arise to discriminate fakes and abusers. Again it will come to the core like devices parts and safety, for example if GPS can be trusted then you could discriminate fakes by location / as long as this cannot be faked, or measured by different parameters too. Or even expect decentralized profiles to interact with reality around, fake profiles (which are based  on thousands of other fake profiles) could have it hard to generate interactions recorded in the network (example someone from the network visiting my office, so I record that event).

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> @NWhiskeyTango So the most decentralized is to never change anything ever again once it's launched? :P
Anyway, #announcements explains what the teams considers best. There's nothing strange to it. It's how blockchains work. The work is open source and can be forked to whomever's liking. But for obvious reasons you'd do best in following the development team's fork, and in that case the development team can be considered the centralized part of a project. And lastly, it's not about banning fpga:s, it's about leveling the playing field in this point in time, mostly until fpgas become more common(decentralized). (As I interpret it)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <stretcher83> I think , when gpu miners came on board for verus , they/we all did it openly, and we all focused on making the project and community better, when the fpga‚Äôs found a way of mining verus, they chose the opposite route, they did it all secretly, swerving the open community that we had all built up, and then they started to pump and dump , which has had ill effects on not just the price of the verus coin but also the community, i think if they decided to just be open to us all with the fpga miner, yes some of us would have been a bit miffed off that the net hash and difficulty was about to go up , but i think we would have worked through it and added a new lot of members to our community, as it is now , i dont see the fpga crew trying to better the community and the project , i just see them as still being secretive and deceptive towards the community, i totally get your point of view NWhiskeyTango , i think its a shame now with everything thats gone on , we have two separate verus communities, one with cpu and gpu , and the other with fpga‚Äôs , i wish we could go back and try it again a different way , a more open way where we would then have 1 big friendly verus community with fpga‚Äôs and cpu and gpu miners all working together , the proper way , i still have high hopes that some fpga miners will openly join our community and work with us for the future of the project , fingers crossed

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> @NWhiskeyTango Yes the goal is decentralization. Not who complains loudest. The issue isnt about stopping anybody and as gloryman said, it is mostly about leveling the playing field and as jl777c said fpga currently have over 50x lead meaning more coins going to a few. This leads to centralization. A group decision is not centralization. If you've been following in here lately, you will find the community is very much united on most of these matters and from the frequent updates and inquiries by Mike and the dev team it leads me to believe that they are flexible and open minded. Who knows, stick around, that cpu might prove useful!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <cryptonoobie> I understand where you guys are coming from.  Not being particularly knowledgeable about the dynamics of mining and all of the different strategies, I don't see how FPGAs could ever be a part of the Verus community.  The goal here is to keep processors of  any type as equitable as possible.  This goes against what the FPGA is supposed to do -- do something extraordinarily fast.  Right?  So with this in mind, I would expect that once the fork comes out, maintain parity between the CPU and GPU as before and lock out the FPGAs enough that there is no incentive to use them anymore.  FPGAs can target other coins.   Or maybe there's something in between where a new algo requires CPU users to get any cheap GPU to use functions that make it impossible for FPGAs?  I don't know, just wondering actually.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> "From the very beginning of its operation, Verus operated with a dual proof of stake /
proof of work mechanism for all participants. Verus mining with the VerusHash algorithm,
as of this point, is a CPU-only algorithm, designed with a Haraka512 V2 [30] core to be
quantum secure and to maximize performance on modern CPUs. While VerusHash was
designed to be CPU-optimized and did not begin life with GPU or ASIC miners capable of
beating CPUs in its mining, the Verus developers have no illusions that it is possible someone
might develop either a GPU or ASIC-based miner that could be meaningfully superior to
CPUs."
